Banka Slovenije zaostrila pogoje pri kreditiranju prebivalstva
01 Nov 2019, 19:24 by STA

Banke bodo morale pri kreditiranju prebivalstva odslej upoštevati nove minimalne standarde, ki jih je postavila Banka Slovenije. Pri potrošniških posojilih je omejila ročnost, pri potrošniških in stanovanjskih pa razmerje med letnim stroškom servisiranja dolga in letnim neto dohodkom kreditojemalca. Nova pravila so poskrbela za precej razburjenja.



Foto: Daniel Novakovic/STA

LJUBLJANA > Ročnost novo odobrenega potrošniškega posojila je lahko odslej do največ sedem let oziroma 84 mesecev. Razmerje med letnim stroškom servisiranja dolga in letnim neto dohodkom kreditojemalca ne sme presegati 50 odstotkov za osebe z dohodki do dvakratnika bruto minimalne plače in 67 odstotkov za del posojilojemalčevega dohodka, ki presega omenjeni prag. Imetniku kredita bo ob tem po plačilu obroka moralo ostati 76 odstotkov bruto minimalne plače, če ima vzdrževane družinske člane, pa sorazmerno več.
Ukrep Banke Slovenije na področju stanovanjskih posojil ne prinaša bistvenih novosti. Zavezujoč ukrep je razmerje med letnim stroškom servisiranja dolga in letnim neto dohodkom kreditojemalca, ki prav tako ne sme preseči 50 odstotkov za osebe z dohodki do dvakratnika bruto minimalne plače in 67 odstotkov za preostali del dohodka. Priporočilo bankam pa ostaja, da razmerje med zneskom kredita in vrednostjo stanovanjske nepremičnine, s katero je kredit zavarovan, ne presega 80 odstotkov.
Nekatera odstopanja so dovoljena
Pri teh ukrepih so dovoljena nekatera odstopanja. Za potrošniške kredite veljajo do 15 odstotkov zneska novo odobrenih kreditov za instrument omejevanja ročnosti, a ročnost ne sme preseči 10 let, za obe vrsti posojil pa odstopanja veljajo do 10 odstotkov zneska novo odobrenih kreditov za instrument omejevanja razmerja med letnim stroškom servisiranja dolga in letnim neto dohodkom kreditojemalca.
Banka Slovenije se je za uvedbo zavezujočih pravil odločila, ker je pred letom dni bankam izdala priporočila, a ugotovila, da jih te ne upoštevajo v zadostni meri. Ocenila je namreč, da se tveganja, povezana predvsem s potrošniškim kreditiranjem prebivalstva, povečujejo. Rast potrošniških kreditov je namreč že precej časa zelo visoka, avgusta je medletno znašala 11,7 odstotka.
V Združenju bank Slovenije nezadovoljni
“Bistvo tega ukrepa je, da poseže v prekomerno kreditiranje. Zavedamo se, da v tem trenutku v Sloveniji kar nekaj prebivalcev ne more pridobiti določenih dobrin, da jim tega ne omogočajo njihove plače oziroma splošna razvitost, ki jo imamo v Sloveniji, ampak če tem ljudem dejemo lažno iluzijo, da si te dobrine lahko kupijo s posojili, ki jih že danes težko odplačujejo, še težje pa jih bodo odplačevali po tem, ko se bodo gospodarske razmere zaostrile /.../, to predstavlja nevarnost tako zanje kot za banke, ki takšna posojila dajejo, in, kot smo videli v primeru prejšnje finančne krize, na koncu tudi za državo, proračun oziroma za davkoplačevalce, ki bomo to škodo na koncu plačali,” je ta teden za TV Slovenija poudaril guverner Banke Slovenija Boštjan Vasle.
Medtem so zaradi ukrepa bančnega nadzornika nezadovoljni v Združenju bank Slovenije. Omejitev pri kreditiranju prebivalstva bo imela po njihovi oceni širše posledice, če država prebivalcem ne bo ponudila alternativnih virov financiranja. Zaradi ukrepa več kot 300.000 ljudi ne bo več dobilo posojil, negativen bo tudi vpliv na BDP, so ocenili pred dnevi in dodali, da se bo kreditiranje zmanjšalo do 70 milijonov evrov mesečno. Podobno negativno so do ukrepa Banke Slovenije nastrojeni trgovci.
V zgodbo je ta teden posegel tudi premier Marjan Šarec. V sporočilu za javnost je ocenil, da gre za premalo premišljen ukrep, ozko in predvsem računovodsko usmerjen, v škodo ljudi in tudi države oz. gospodarske rasti. Pri pripravi ukrepov bi morali biti po njegovem prepričanju bolj človeški in realni, zato je banke in Banko Slovenije pozval k vnovičnemu premisleku.

The Bank of Slovenia tightened lending conditions
01 Nov 2019, 18:24 by STA

Banks will now have to comply with the new minimum standards set by the Bank of Slovenia in retail lending. For consumer loans, it reduced maturity and for consumer and home loans the ratio between the annual cost of debt servicing and the borrower's annual net income. The new rules provided a lot of excitement.



Photo: Daniel Novakovic / STA

LJUBLJANA> The maturity of a newly approved consumer loan can now be up to seven years or 84 months. The ratio of the annual cost of debt servicing to the borrower's annual net income may not exceed 50 percent for those with an income up to twice the gross minimum wage and 67 percent for a portion of the borrower's income beyond the said threshold. The creditor will then have to remain at 76 percent of the gross minimum wage after the installment has been paid, or if he or she has dependents, a proportionate increase.
The Bank of Slovenia's action in the field of housing loans does not bring any significant changes. The binding measure is the ratio of the annual cost of debt servicing to the borrower's annual net income, which may also not exceed 50 percent for people with incomes up to twice the gross minimum wage and 67 percent for the rest of their income. The recommendation to banks, however, is that the ratio between the loan amount and the value of the residential property with which the loan is secured does not exceed 80 percent.
Some tolerances are allowed
These measures allow for certain derogations. Consumer loans are subject to up to 15 percent of the amount of newly approved loans for a maturity restriction, but maturity may not exceed 10 years, and for both types of loans, derogations apply up to 10 percent of the amount of newly approved loans to limit the relationship between the annual debt service cost and the annual net the borrower's income.
The Bank of Slovenia decided to introduce binding rules because a year ago it issued recommendations to banks, but found that they did not sufficiently follow them. It estimated that the risks related mainly to consumer lending to households were increasing. Consumer credit growth has been very high for quite some time now, reaching 11.7 percent year-on-year in August.
The Banking Association of Slovenia is dissatisfied
“The point of this measure is to resort to over-lending. We are aware that at the moment, quite a few people in Slovenia cannot acquire certain goods, that their wages or the general development we have in Slovenia do not allow them, but if we give these people the false illusion that they can buy these goods with loans that are difficult to repay today, but even more difficult to repay after the economic conditions deteriorate / ... /, this poses a risk to them as well as to the banks that make such loans and, as we have seen in in the event of the previous financial crisis, and ultimately for the state, the budget and for the taxpayers, who will eventually pay for this damage, ”Bank of Slovenia Governor Boštjan Vasle pointed out to TV Slovenia this week.
In the meantime, they are dissatisfied with the Banking Association of Slovenia due to the action of the banking supervisor. Limitations on lending to households will, in their estimation, have wider implications if the country does not offer alternative sources of financing to the population. As a result of the measure, more than 300,000 people will no longer receive loans, the impact on GDP will also be negative, estimates were made days ago, adding that lending will be reduced by up to € 70 million a month. Similarly, the Bank of Slovenia measure has a negative attitude towards merchants.
Prime Minister Marjan Sarec also reached the story this week. In a press release, he estimated that this was an insufficiently thoughtful measure, narrowly and primarily accounting-oriented, to the detriment of the people, as well as of the state or the state. economic growth. According to him, the measures should be more human and realistic when drafting the measures, which is why he called on the banks and the Bank of Slovenia to reconsider.
